Initial client contact on April 16, 2021 with Destiny Adkins regarding a motor vehicle accident (case Destiny-Adkins-MVA-04-16-2021).

We are currently representing Destiny on another case that likely has no bodily injury. That accident occurred about two weeks after this one, and we never added this case.

Please check with Destiny regarding any treatments or hospital visits that occurred in the interval between the two accidents. This was a pretty bad accident.

__Adkins & Downs v Nail & Allstate__
From: Sarena Tuttle [sarena@whaleylawfirm.com](mailto:sarena@whaleylawfirm.com)
To: Aaron Whaley [agwhaley@whaleylawfirm.com](mailto:agwhaley@whaleylawfirm.com)
CC: 
Date: Thu, 23 Jun 2022 15:24:23 -0400

Hey AW,
 Campbell Ewen called today, he was a bit confused on why we filed suit
against Allstate in this matter. We discussed the fact the vehicle was
reported stolen AFTER the incident not prior as the police report stated
and Allstate denied the claim without further investigation.
 After our conversation, he requested a 60 day extension to answer the
complaint on behalf of Allstate as he would like to discuss possibly
accepting coverage with his client before answering.

Sarena M. Tuttle
The Whaley Law Firm
712 Lyndon Lane
Louisville, KY 40222
D: (502) 365-9435
O: (502) 583-4022
E: Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com
(PLEASE NOTE NEW EMAIL ADDRESS)
episodes.natural_language:
Destiny-Adkins-MVA-04-16-2021 concerns client Destiny Adkins. In the Adkins & Downs v Nail & Allstate matter, an email dated June 23, 2022 at 3:24 PM Eastern was sent from Sarena M. Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm to Aaron Whaley regarding the suit against Allstate.

In the message, Sarena notes that Campbell Ewen called that day and was somewhat confused about why we filed suit against Allstate in this matter. They discussed that the vehicle was reported stolen after the incident, not prior as the police report stated, and that Allstate denied the claim without further investigation. After the conversation, Ewen requested a 60-day extension to answer the complaint on behalf of Allstate, as he would like to discuss possibly accepting coverage with his client before answering.

Sarena M. Tuttle

Louisville, KY 40222

episodes.original_body:
Case: Destiny-Adkins-MVA-04-16-2021
Client: Destiny Adkins

Recvd call from Allstate DC Campbell Ewen - Confused as to why Allstate was named as a Defendant - Discussed fact vehicle was reported after MVA not 30 minutes prior as PR stated - Provided Theft & Crime Report - DC Requested 60 day extension to answer complaint while he discusses coverage acceptance w/Allstate - Sent Request to AW for approval - Awaiting AW Response #dc #extension #lit
episodes.natural_language:
Case: Destiny-Adkins-MVA-04-16-2021. Client: Destiny Adkins.

The office received a call from Campbell Ewen of Allstate regarding the Destiny Adkins motor vehicle accident matter. Ewen was confused as to why Allstate was named as a Defendant. During the conversation, it was clarified that the vehicle involved in the MVA was reported after the accident, not 30 minutes prior as stated in the police report (PR). The Theft & Crime Report was provided to Allstate. Campbell Ewen requested a 60-day extension to answer the complaint while he discusses coverage acceptance with Allstate. A request was sent to AW for approval, and we are awaiting AW’s response.
episodes.author: Sarena Tuttle

about.relevance: Allstate representative who called and requested extension

Destiny Adkins is the client in the case titled Destiny-Adkins-MVA-04-16-2021, the matter captioned Adkins & Downs v Nail & Allstate.

In the matter, Sarena M. Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm (712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222) communicated with A. Campbell Ewen (ACEwen@ewenandkinney.com) regarding two related emails. On June 23, 2022 at 3:11 PM, Tuttle wrote to Campbell Ewen, stating: “Good afternoon Campbell, Please find attached all of the documents we discussed this afternoon. Hopefully these will help clear up some confusion.” Her signature block listed The Whaley Law Firm’s contact details: direct line 502-365-9435, office line 502-583-4022, email Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com, with a note to please (PLEASE NOTE NEW EMAIL ADDRESS).

The following day, June 24, 2022 at 9:30:12 AM, Tuttle wrote again to Mr. Ewen: “Good morning Mr. Ewen, I spoke with Aaron after our conversation and he is fine with a sixty (60) day extension to answer the complaint on behalf of Allstate. If you need anything further please let me know.” This message was also signed by Sarena M. Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm, with the same office address and contact numbers, and the same email, Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com, again noting the new email address.

On June 30, 2022, at 6:25:49 p.m. UTC, Brian D. Stempien of Travis Herbert & Stempien, PLLC wrote to Sarena Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm (cc’ing A. Campbell Ewen and Aaron Whaley) seeking clarification about the status of service. His question was: “As far as we could see, the return of service stated only COVID 19. What information do you have that shows this as being good service?” His signature block lists his firm’s address at the Jefferson Marders Building, 11507 Main Street, Middletown Historic District, Louisville, KY 40243, with office phone (502) 245-7474, fax (502) 245-7025, toll-free (1-866-431-3599), email bstempien@thattorneys.com, and website http://www.thslaw.co. The email includes standard attorney-privilege and confidentiality notices, along with the IRS Circular 230 tax disclosure, and a disclaimer about there being no attorney-client relationship created by sending or receiving the email.

In response, on June 30, 2022, at 2:20 p.m., Sarena M. Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm replied. She thanked Stempien for the letter dated June 28, 2022 notifying representation of Stephanie Nail at Allstate’s request. She stated that, per CourtNet, Stephanie Nail was served via Certified Mail on June 15, 2022, and she indicated that the firm would look forward to receiving an Answer on or about July 15, 2022. She expressed openness to settlement discussions and noted that, in the meantime, Interrogatories and the Complaint had been propounded/served on June 15, 2022, and attached them to the message. Her signature block provides contact details for The Whaley Law Firm: 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; Direct line (502) 365-9435; Office line (502) 583-4022; email Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com, with a parenthetical note to “PLEASE NOTE NEW EMAIL ADDRESS.”

The email thread includes the original correspondence and attachments referenced by Sarena: the Interrogatories and the Complaint dated June 15, 2022. The communication also notes the new email address for Sarena Tuttle and is part of a dispute over service of process and potential settlement discussions in the Adkins & Downs v. Nail matter.

Destiny Adkins is the client in the matter Destiny-Adkins-MVA-04-16-2021, captioned Adkins & Downs v Stephanie Nail & Allstate. On June 30, 2022, Sarena M. Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm sent an email to Brian D. Stempien of Travis Herbert & Stempien, PLLC (on behalf of Stephanie Nail at the request of Allstate) regarding service of process in that case. The subject line of the correspondence was Adkins & Downs v Stephanie Nail & Allstate. The email was addressed to Stempien with copies to A. Campbell Ewen and Aaron Whaley, and was sent from Sarena Tuttle at The Whaley Law Firm, located at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222. Her direct lines were D: (502) 365-9435 and O: (502) 583-4022, and her email was Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com (noting a new email address).

Earlier that day, at 2:20 PM, Sarena wrote to Mr. Stempien noting that settlement discussions were welcome if the office wished to make an offer. She stated that, per CourtNet, Nail’s client had been served via Certified Mail on 06/15/2022, and she expected to receive an Answer on behalf of Mrs. Nail on or about 07/15/2022. She advised that if settlement discussions were needed, they could be had directly; in the meantime, she attached the Interrogatories propounded upon the client and the Complaint dated 06/15/2022, and invited discussion about the claim in more detail. The email included her firm’s contact information and carried the standard firm signature, which again listed The Whaley Law Firm’s address and her phone numbers and email, with a note to “PLEASE NOTE NEW EMAIL ADDRESS.”

At 2:25 PM, Brian Stempien replied, asking what information demonstrated good service, because, in his view, the return of service stated only COVID-19. His message included his firm’s details: Travis Herbert & Stempien, PLLC, located in the Jefferson Marders Building, 11507 Main Street, Middletown Historic District, Louisville, KY 40243; Office: (502) 245-7474; Fax: (502) 245-7025; Toll Free: 1 (866) 431-3599; E-Mail: bstempien@thattorneys.com; Web: http://www.thslaw.co. The email was accompanied by the firm’s standard Privileged and Confidential disclaimer, noting that the information is attorney privileged and confidential and not intended for unauthorized recipients, and that no attorney-client relationship is formed by sending or receiving email.

In reply, at 2:37 PM, Sarena stated that the question of whether service is “good” or not is not for her to decide, and that service is listed as “Successful.” She noted that if the opposing party wished to file an Answer and then dispute the validity of service, that was up to them and/or their client, and she would note the concern for Aaron to address further. She signed again with her Whaley Law Firm contact details.

The thread also contained standard email disclosures and signatures. The messages carried the usual Attorney Privilege and Confidentiality notices, a disclaimer that no Attorney-Client Relationship is created by email, and the IRS Circular 230 warning regarding tax advice. The emails also contained a Proofpoint Essentials note indicating that the messages had been scanned for spam and viruses, and included an embedded image reference. The attachments referenced in the messages were the Interrogatories and the Complaint served on 06/15/2022.

Aaron and Ms. Tuttle:

With respect to service, I would simply note that the return actually attached to the electronic file on Courtnet just simply has the work COVID spelled out. Our position at this time is that this is not effective service. If you disagree or intend to file a motion for default, please let us know.

Second, while I should have confirmed at the time, my recollection is that we discussed a 30 day extension of the time to Answer by agreement. At this point, please let me know if you are opposed to an extension through August 1.

Finally, do you intend to move to amend the Complaint? If so, perhaps we should just wait to see what happens when you try to serve that on Ms. Nail.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Destiny-Adkins-MVA-04-16-2021. The client is Destiny Adkins, and the matter is styled Adkins & Downs v. Stephanie Nail & Allstate. The communications spanning June and July 2022 involve counsel for Destiny’s side—the Whaley Law Firm—and counsel for Stephanie Nail’s side—Travis Herbert & Stempien, PLLC—with several recipients CC’d, including Sarena Tuttle, A. Campbell Ewen, and Beth Alexander. The exchange centers on service of process, extensions of time to respond, and potential amendment or settlement discussions in the underlying case following Destiny Adkins’s motor vehicle accident on April 16, 2021.

On June 30, 2022, Sarena M. Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm sent an email to Brian D. Stempien of Travis Herbert & Stempien, PLLC, with Aaron Whaley and A. Campbell Ewen also copied. In this message, Tuttle thanked Stempien for his letter dated June 28, 2022 noting representation of Stephanie Nail at the request of Allstate. She stated that the firm is open to settlement discussions at any time and, if an offer is forthcoming, is willing to discuss. However, she noted, per CourtNet, that Stephanie Nail had been served via Certified Mail on June 15, 2022, and Destiny’s team looked forward to receiving Nail’s Answer on or about July 15, 2022. Tuttle also advised that if further discussion or information was needed regarding settlement, contact could be made directly to discuss the claim in more detail, and she attached the Interrogatories propounded upon Nail along with the Complaint dated June 15, 2022. The message listed Sarena M. Tuttle’s contact information, including the Louisville, Kentucky address (712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222) and phone numbers, and noted a new email address for correspondence. The email also included the customary firm signatures and disclaimers, including spam/virus scan notation from Proofpoint Essentials and the standard “Privileged and Confidential,” “No Attorney-Client Relationship,” andIRS Circular 230 disclosures typically accompanying such correspondence, as well as the firm’s disclaimer about the limitations of tax advice and the prohibition against using the document for marketing purposes. The message also contained the sender’s and recipients’ respective email signatures and contact details.

On July 14, 2022, at approximately 10:50 a.m., Brian D. Stempien replied to Aaron Whaley and Sarena Tuttle. He commented on service: the return attached to the electronic file on CourtNet allegedly shows the word “COVID” spelled out, and he stated that, in his view, this does not constitute effective service. He asked to be informed if there is a disagreement or if a motion for default is planned. He then recalled, or stated his recollection, that there had been a discussion about a 30-day extension of the time to Answer by agreement, and he asked to know whether the opposing party would be opposed to extending through August 1. He also asked whether the clients intended to move to amend the Complaint and suggested that if amendment is planned, it might be prudent to wait to see what happens when Nail is served with the amended complaint. The email concluded with Stempien’s standard contact information for Travis Herbert & Stempien, PLLC, including address in the Jefferson Marders Building, Louisville, KY, and telephone numbers, as well as the firm’s website.

At 11:02 a.m. on the same day, July 14, 2022, Aaron Whaley responded to Stempien. He stated that he had no objection to an extension through August 1, and that if Allstate were to extend coverage, he would have no objection to an indefinite extension while he attempted to resolve the claim with Allstate. His reply was also copied to Sarena Tuttle, A. Campbell Ewen, and Beth Alexander, and it was sent from Whaley’s email address agwhaley@whaleylawfirm.com.

The record also reiterates that the parties referenced the CourtNet status with Nail’s service by Certified Mail on June 15, 2022, and there is ongoing discussion about extending deadlines, service validity, and the possibility of amending the Complaint. The messages include typical case-specific content such as the inquiry about a default motion should service be challenged, and whether an extension to August 1 would be opposed. The communications also reflect that counsel contemplated potential settlement discussions, the status of Nail’s service, and the procedural steps necessary to move the case forward, including whether to serve an amended complaint.

In addition to the substantive exchange, the emails carried standard firm-specific formalities: the July 14 emails included the usual privileged/confidentiality notices, no attorney-client relationship disclosures, and disclaimers regarding the IRS Circular 230 regulations governing tax advice in written communications. The correspondence also included boilerplate language about email disclaimers and the sender’s firm identity, with the final contact details for Aaron Whaley and The Whaley Law Firm in Louisville, Kentucky.

In sum, the matter Destiny Adkins v. Stephanie Nail & Allstate involved an ongoing dialogue in mid-2022 about service validity, deadlines to answer, potential amendments to the Complaint, and possible settlement discussions, all within the context of Destiny Adkins’s motor vehicle accident case arising on April 16, 2021. The parties agreed to consider extensions and contested service in the Courtnet record, while counsel also exchanged positions on settlement opportunities and the proper handling of the complaint and any amended pleadings.

Destiny Adkins is the client in the Destiny-Adkins-MVA-04-16-2021 matter, arising from a motor vehicle accident on April 16, 2021. The office received a request from DC Stempien for an extension to answer the complaint, with Stempien’s position that service on the complaint had not been effectuated (not effective service). They requested a Notice of Intent to File Default if we decide to proceed, and they also asked whether we intended to amend the complaint, noting, “perhaps we should just wait to see what happens when you try to serve that on Ms. Nail.”

episodes.natural_language:
Case Destiny-Adkins-MVA-04-16-2021, involving client Destiny Adkins.

The notes show that a DC LOR for Defendant Nail was received. Destiny Adkins’ team stated that the defendant would file an answer upon service.

We replied advising that the service was Successful on 06/15/2022 and that we looked forward to his Answer on or about 07/15/2022. He responded asking, "What information do you have that shows this as being good service?" We replied that the validity of 'good' service is not up to us, and that the service is listed as Successful. While I acknowledge he has a point (see attached POS), it remains up to the court to determine whether it is 'good' service or 'bad' service. How would you like to proceed?

Case: Destiny-Adkins-MVA-04-16-2021
Client: Destiny Adkins

__Your Personal Injury Claim - Defense Discovery Request__
From: Sarena Tuttle [sarena@whaleylawfirm.com](mailto:sarena@whaleylawfirm.com)
To: DestinyAdkins0409@yahoo.com 
CC: 
Date: Wed, 26 Oct 2022 15:30:03 -0400

Good afternoon Destiny,
 Please find attached a set of questions of the defense counsel related
to your motor vehicle accident that took place on April 16, 2021. We have
also mailed a copy via USPS. Please review and answer the questions to the
best of your ability as soon as possible. Your claim can not move forward
until these answers are received.
 We are on a 30 day deadline so these responses need to be provided to
our office before November 17th, 2022 in order to be reviewed and properly
drafted before we return them to the defense counsel. If you have any
questions, please do not hesitate to contact us to discuss them in further
detail.

Sarena M. Tuttle
The Whaley Law Firm
712 Lyndon Lane
Louisville, KY 40222
D: (502) 357-9971
O: (502) 583-4022 ext 104
E: Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com
(PLEASE NOTE NEW EMAIL ADDRESS)
episodes.natural_language:
On October 26, 2022, at 3:30 p.m. Eastern Time, Sarena M. Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm sent an email to Destiny Adkins at DestinyAdkins0409@yahoo.com with the subject “Your Personal Injury Claim - Defense Discovery Request.” The message stated that a set of questions from defense counsel related to Destiny Adkins’s motor vehicle accident, which occurred on April 16, 2021, were attached, and that a copy had also been mailed via USPS. Destiny was asked to review and answer the questions to the best of her ability as soon as possible, with the note that her claim could not move forward until these answers are received.

The email advised that there is a 30-day deadline, and that the responses must be provided to The Whaley Law Firm before November 17, 2022 in order to be reviewed and properly drafted before they are returned to defense counsel. If Destiny had any questions, she was encouraged to contact the firm to discuss them in further detail. The message was signed by Sarena M. Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm, located at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, with direct line (502) 357-9971, office line (502) 583-4022 ext 104, and email Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com, noted as the new email address. (PLEASE NOTE NEW EMAIL ADDRESS)

Initial client contact on April 16, 2021, with Destiny Adkins regarding a motor vehicle accident.

Destiny called to say she had received some paperwork in the mail, which she assumed was discovery, though she did not know its contents. She noted that she had previously answered the same questions with ST and AGW. I told her that ST would call her tomorrow, since ST was not in the office today. The note is marked “#cc.”

Client called in & Left message w/FG - Attempted to return her call - LVM - She then called back and we discussed Discovery Packet - She has been having mail issues and just received - Advised Client if she has any more detailed questions once she goes to answer the requests, she is welcome to give us a call & go over them one by one. #cc #discReq
episodes.natural_language:
On April 16, 2021, Destiny Adkins contacted our office regarding a motor vehicle accident. She initially called in and left a message with FG. We attempted to return her call but only reached voicemail.

She later called back, and we discussed the Discovery Packet. She mentioned that she has been having mail issues and had just received mail. We advised her that if she has any more detailed questions once she begins answering the discovery requests, she is welcome to call us and go over them one by one. This note was marked cc and discReq.

From: Sarena Tuttle [sarena@whaleylawfirm.com](mailto:sarena@whaleylawfirm.com)
To: DestinyAdkins0409@yahoo.com 
CC: 
Date: Thu, 6 Apr 2023 10:32:49 -0400

Good morning Destiny,
 Please give us a call as soon as possible to discuss your responses
to the attached discovery request for your personal injury claim.

Sarena M. Tuttle
Litigation Paralegal &
Workers' Compensation Case Manager
The Whaley Law Firm
712 Lyndon Lane
Louisville, KY 40222
D: (502) 357-9971
O: (502) 583-4022 ext 104
E: Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com
(PLEASE NOTE NEW EMAIL ADDRESS)

On Wed, Oct 26, 2022 at 3:30?PM Sarena Tuttle 
wrote:

> Good afternoon Destiny,
> Please find attached a set of questions of the defense counsel related
> to your motor vehicle accident that took place on April 16, 2021. We have
> also mailed a copy via USPS. Please review and answer the questions to the
> best of your ability as soon as possible. Your claim can not move forward
> until these answers are received.
> We are on a 30 day deadline so these responses need to be provided to
> our office before November 17th, 2022 in order to be reviewed and properly
> drafted before we return them to the defense counsel. If you have any
> questions, please do not hesitate to contact us to discuss them in further
> detail.
>
> Sarena M. Tuttle
> The Whaley Law Firm
> 712 Lyndon Lane
> Louisville, KY 40222
> D: (502) 357-9971
> O: (502) 583-4022 ext 104
> E: Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com
> (PLEASE NOTE NEW EMAIL ADDRESS)
>
episodes.natural_language:
Destiny Adkins is the client in the Destiny-Adkins-MVA-04-16-2021 case, which concerns a motor vehicle accident that occurred on April 16, 2021. On April 6, 2023, she received an email from Sarena M. Tuttle, a litigation paralegal and workers’ compensation case manager at The Whaley Law Firm, regarding a defense discovery request for Destiny’s personal injury claim. The message, sent from sarena@whaleylawfirm.com to DestinyAdkins0409@yahoo.com, asked Destiny to call as soon as possible to discuss her responses to the attached discovery request.

Sarena M. Tuttle’s signature identifies her as a Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, located at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222. The contact numbers listed are D: (502) 357-9971 and O: (502) 583-4022 ext 104, with the email address Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com. The note also includes a reminder to note the new email address.

The note references an earlier communication from Sarena Tuttle, dated Wednesday, October 26, 2022, at 3:30? PM. In that message, she advised Destiny that a set of questions from defense counsel related to the motor vehicle accident on April 16, 2021 was attached and that a copy had also been mailed via USPS. Destiny was asked to review and answer the questions to the best of her ability as soon as possible, as the claim could not move forward until those answers were received. The message stated there was a 30-day deadline, requiring the responses to be provided to the office before November 17, 2022 in order to be reviewed and properly drafted before they would be returned to defense counsel. Destiny was encouraged to contact the office with any questions to discuss them in further detail. The message again provided The Whaley Law Firm’s contact details and reiterated the new email address.
episodes.author: Sarena Tuttle

episodes.natural_language:
In the Destiny-Adkins-MVA case (case file Destiny-Adkins-MVA-04-16-2021) for client Destiny Adkins, the notes concern responses to a DC discovery request in the Adkins & Downs v Nail, Allstate & Unk Driver matter. On Thursday, April 6, 2023, at 11:53:42 a.m. Eastern Time, Sarena Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm sent an email to Aaron Whaley, with Joel Franklin cc’d, providing Adkins’ response to the DC Disc Req for approval prior to submission. In that message she described the client as difficult to communicate with and seem­ing disinterested in the case, and she noted that scheduling a deposition would be difficult.

Sarena’s email signature in that message reiterated her role as a Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, with the firm’s address at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, and the contact numbers D: (502) 357-9971 and O: (502) 583-4022 ext 104. Her email was listed as Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com, with a note indicating this is a new address.

Earlier that same day, around 9:48 a.m., Sarena wrote that they had requested cell phone information via IROGs but had not yet received the defendants’ answers.

In the thread from the prior day, Wednesday, April 5, 2023, Aaron Whaley had asked at 6:36 p.m. whether cell records had been requested on this case yet.

Earlier still, at 3:40 p.m. on April 5, Sarena wrote: “Hey guys, please find attached the Resp to DC Nail’s Disc Req for Juanita Downs. Please review for approval before sending to DC & Filing NOS w/ Jefferson County Circuit Court.” She noted that the companion case for Destiny Adkins’ responses was in progress, and she highlighted that the Theft/Crime Report shows the vehicle was reported stolen AFTER the MVA, not before, attaching the file “2023.04.05 Downs Resp to DC Disc Req.pdf.”

Sarena’s message again carried her signature with the same firm details and new email address. The thread also included the closing signature from Aaron Whaley, with his firm’s name, address at 712 Lyndon Ln, Louisville, KY 40222, and his contact number at 502-583-4022.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Destiny-Adkins-MVA-04-16-2021. The client is Destiny Adkins, and the matter is styled Adkins & Downs v Stephanie Nail & Allstate.

On April 21, 2023 at 2:42 PM (the email header shows “Fri, 21 Apr 2023 14:42:21 -0400”), Aaron Whaley of Whaley Law Firm forwarded a message to Sarena Tuttle regarding the Adkins & Downs v Nail & Allstate matter. The forwarded thread begins with a note from Brian D. Stempien of Travis Herbert & Stempien, PLLC, responding to Aaron. Brian wrote that his carrier is pressuring him to file a motion to compel and asked for updates on deposition dates and discovery. He signed the message with the firm’s full contact information: Travis Herbert & Stempien, PLLC, Jefferson Marders Building, 11507 Main Street, Middletown Historic District, Louisville, KY 40243; Office: (502) 245-7474; Fax: (502) 245-7025; Toll Free: 1-866-431-3599; E-Mail: bstempien@thattorneys.com; Web: http://www.thslaw.co. The email contains the standard Privileged and Confidential notice indicating that the information is intended for the named recipient and that no attorney-client relationship is formed by sending or receiving the email, along with the sender’s and recipient’s acknowledgement of that disclaimer. The message also includes the IRS Circular 230 tax disclosure warning, explaining that the document may not contain all required tax disclosures and that tax advice should not be relied upon to avoid penalties.

In the chain, there is a preceding exchange from Aaron Whaley dated March 22, 2023 at 9:37 AM, which states that they were working on completing discovery responses and dates, and acknowledges a minor miscommunication with Sarena about redoing service due to a prior objection.

The thread also contains a prior message from Brian Stempien dated March 21, 2023 at 5:02 PM. In that email, Brian asked when they could expect the client’s discovery responses and deposition dates. He noted that they had received a “peculiar filing of the complaint again today” and asked whether that was intentional or if there was anything missing. He stated a desire to close the loop on Ms. Nail’s discovery and indicated that obtaining the client’s responses and her deposition should be their first priority.

In addition to the April 2023 exchange, the thread includes older correspondence from July 2022. On July 14, 2022, at 11:03 AM, Aaron Whaley replied to Brian Stempien (with Sarena Tuttle, A. Campbell Ewen, and Beth Alexander cc’d) indicating that he had no objection to an extension to August 1 and, if Allstate extended coverage, would object to an indefinite extension while attempting to resolve the claim with Allstate.

Earlier that same day, July 14, 2022 at 10:50 AM, Brian Stempien sent a message to Aaron and Ms. Tuttle with an important service-related discussion. He noted that the return attached to the electronic file on Courtnet spelled the word “COVID,” and stated his position that this was not effective service. He asked Aaron to indicate if they disagreed or if they intended to file a motion for default. Brian also recalled that they had discussed a 30-day extension of the time to Answer by agreement and asked to know whether there was opposition to extending through August 1. He further asked whether Aaron intended to move to amend the Complaint and suggested that they might wait to see what happens when attempting to serve Nail.

The July 2022 correspondence also shows the standard confidential and privileged-notice markings common to communications from these law firms, including the same No Attorney-Client Relationship disclaimer and the Circular 230 tax-disclosure language.

The emails include the usual contact details for the parties’ counsel. Aaron Whaley’s messages and the forwarded communications reference the ongoing discovery and deposition scheduling in the Adkins & Downs v Nail & Allstate matter, with Brian Stempien representing the opposing side and requesting timely responses and dates, while Aaron and Sarena Tuttle coordinate the client’s discovery responses and service issues. The case remains a motor vehicle accident matter involving Destiny Adkins, with the case caption reflecting Adkins as a plaintiff and Stephanie Nail and Allstate as defendants. The communications also reference the law firms’ offices and contact information, including Travis Herbert & Stempien, PLLC in Louisville, and Whaley Law Firm, with their respective emails and websites, and the standard protective disclaimers that accompany professional emails in this matter.

Case: Destiny-Adkins-MVA-04-16-2021. Client: Destiny Adkins. In the matter captioned Adkins & Downs v Stephanie Nail & Allstate, a series of email exchanges in 2023 reflects ongoing discovery and deposition scheduling. On June 2, 2023, at 17:38:51 UTC, Brian D. Stempien of Travis Herbert & Stempien, PLLC, wrote to Aaron Whaley and Sarena Tuttle with the Whaley Law Firm. He proposed trying to set the depositions of the opposing clients in June if possible and asked Sarena to contact Beth (Beth Alexander) regarding dates and other details; he also asked Aaron to call him when he had a moment. Stempien’s signature block lists the firm’s address in Louisville, KY, along with office, fax, toll-free numbers, email, and website, followed by the standard Privileged and Confidential disclaimer, the No Attorney-Client Relationship notice, and an IRS Circular 230 tax warning.

Earlier, on April 24, 2023, at 11:36 AM, Sarena M. Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm replied to Brian, apologizing for the delay and attaching the Plaintiff’s responses to the discovery requests. She stated that depositions were flexible and asked whether Brian and his client were available on May 23, 25, 30, or June 1, noting that depositions could be conducted via Zoom or at Brian’s office. The message references three attachments: “2023.04.18 Adkins & Downs NOS Resp to DC Disc R...” and two others named “2023.04.18 Adkins Resp to Disc Req - Final.pdf” and “2023.04.18 Downs Resp to Disc Req - Final.pdf.” The email footer includes Sarena’s contact information, including her title, the firm’s address at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, direct line, office line with extension 104, and her new email address, Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com, followed by the standard Privileged and Confidential disclaimer and related notices.

The April 21, 2023 chain of messages shows a forwarded note from Brian Stempien, dated April 21, 2023, at 2:09 PM (times rendered as “2:09?PM” in the record). In this message, Brian told Aaron Whaley that his carrier was pressuring him to file a motion to compel and requested updates on deposition dates and discovery. The email ends with Stempien’s signature block and the customary disclaimer about privilege and relationship.

Earlier still, on March 22, 2023, Aaron Whaley replied to Brian Stempien at 9:37 AM, indicating that they were working on finishing the discovery responses and noting a bit of confusion between himself and Sarena. Aaron mentioned that he had assigned Sarena a task to redo service due to a prior objection.

Finally, on March 21, 2023, at 5:02 PM (noted as “5:02?PM” in the record), Brian Stempien wrote to Aaron Whaley. He asked when they could expect the client’s discovery responses and dates for the deposition. He also mentioned receiving a peculiar filing of the complaint again that day and inquired whether it was intentional or if there was anything missing. He stated that they were working to close the loop on Ms. Nail’s discovery but wanted the client’s responses and her deposition set on the books as a top priority. Stempien’s message included his firm’s contact information and the standard privileged/relationship disclaimers.

Across these communications, the exchanges consistently reference depositions, discovery responses, and scheduling, with multiple attachments and negotiations over dates and methods (in-person vs. Zoom). The emails consistently include the Privileged and Confidential notices, the no attorney-client relationship disclaimer, and the Circular 230 tax warning.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Destiny-Adkins-MVA-04-16-2021. Client: Destiny Adkins. The matter referenced is Adkins & Downs v Stephanie Nail & Allstate.

In March and April of 2023, counsel exchanged a series of emails regarding discovery responses and the scheduling of depositions. On March 21, 2023, Brian Stempien wrote to Aaron Whaley asking, “When can we expect your client’s discovery response,” noting that his carrier was pressing him to file a motion to compel. Brian’s signature block followed, displaying his firm, Travis Herbert & Stempien, PLLC, with the office address at 11507 Main Street, Middletown Historic District, Louisville, KY 40243, along with office phone, fax, toll-free number, and email. The footer of this and other emails contained the standard Privileged and Confidential notice, a statement that there is no attorney-client relationship, and the Treasury Circular 230 tax-disclosure warning.

On March 22, 2023, Aaron Whaley replied: “Brian, we are working on getting those responses finished. A little confusion between myself and Sarena. I had sent her a task to redo service since you had raised a prior objection.” This reply continued with Aaron’s signature block and the same customary disclaimers regarding privilege, no attorney-client relationship, and the IRS tax disclosure requirements.

Later, on April 21, 2023, Brian forwarded a message to Aaron (and carbon-copied Beth Alexander) stating that his carrier was pressuring him to file a motion to compel and requesting information about deposition dates and discovery. The forwarded message was part of the ongoing exchange between the firms, and Brian again provided his contact details and the standard legal-disclaimer footer.

On April 24, 2023, Sarena Tuttle, the litigation paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager for The Whaley Law Firm, replied to Brian (and with Aaron CC’d). She apologized for the delay and advised that the Plaintiff’s Responses to the Discovery Request were attached. She also stated that they were flexible on deposition dates and asked whether Brian and his client were available on May 23, 25, 30, or June 1, noting that depositions could be conducted either via Zoom or in Brian’s office. Sarena’s signature block followed, including her contact information at The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, with the direct line and the office line, and her new email address Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com.

On June 2, 2023, Brian sent another message to Aaron and Sarena: “Let’s try to get the depositions of your clients set in June if that will work. Please contact Beth concerning dates, etc.” He further asked Aaron to call him when he had a moment. Brian’s message carried his firm’s contact information and the standard disclaimers.

Then, on June 6, 2023, Sarena Tuttle responded to Brian (and included Beth Alexander in the thread). She stated that their office was available on June 20, 22, 27, or 29 for the depositions and that they would like to take Mrs. Nail’s deposition on the same day, anticipating that the proceeding would take a full day for all three depositions.

Throughout these communications, the governing case remained Destiny Adkins as the client, and the matter at issue was Adkins & Downs v Stephanie Nail & Allstate. The depositions were being coordinated for June, with the Nail deposition to be scheduled on the same day as the others, and the participation of all three depositions anticipated to require a full day. The messages also reflect prior discussions about discovery responses, including the attachment of the Plaintiff’s Responses, and various scheduling options (in-person or via Zoom) as the parties worked to resolve deposition dates and related discovery issues. The communications include standard attorney disclaimers and contact information typical of the firms involved: The Whaley Law Firm (Sarena Tuttle) and Travis Herbert & Stempien, PLLC (Brian Stempien), with the respective addresses, phone numbers, emails, and the acknowledged warnings about privilege, no attorney-client relationship, and tax disclosures.

Case: Destiny-Adkins-MVA-04-16-2021. Client: Destiny Adkins.

In the matter of Adkins & Downs v Stephanie Nail & Allstate, the depositions scheduling discussions involved Destiny Adkins and several counsel and staff from two law firms. The earliest relevant communications in this thread begin with an email from Beth Alexander, paralegal to Brian Stempien of Travis Herbert & Stempien, to Sarena Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm (with copies to Brian Stempien and Aaron Whaley) on June 6, 2023. Beth notes that June 29 is the only date on which Brian is available to take two depositions in one day, and that Brian will not agree to three depositions in a single day. She asks Sarena to propose dates, perhaps the following week, to schedule Ms. Nail’s deposition at their office. Beth provides her contact information: Beth A. Alexander, Paralegal to Brian Stempien, Travis Herbert & Stempien, Jefferson Marders Building, 11507 Main Street, Louisville, KY 40243; phone 502-245-7474; fax 502-245-7025. The email thread includes standard attorney‑client privilege and confidentiality notices.

Earlier in the chain, Sarena Tuttle responds to Beth on the same day, June 6, 2023, at 10:51 AM. She states that their office is available for depositions on June 20, 22, 27, or 29, and that they would like to take Mrs. Nail’s deposition on the same day, anticipating a full day to cover all three depositions. Sarena signs as Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager for The Whaley Law Firm, with the firm’s Louisville address at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222. Her direct line is 502-357-9971, main line 502-583-4022 ext 104, and her email is Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com, noting that it is a new address. This message also contains the standard privilege disclaimer and confidentiality notices.

The thread also contains prior scheduling discussions. On June 2, 2023, Brian Stempien wrote to Aaron Whaley and Sarena, urging that the depositions be scheduled in June if possible, and asking them to contact Beth concerning dates. He also asked Aaron to call him when possible. Brian’s contact details are listed as Travis Herbert & Stempien, Jefferson Marders Building, 11507 Main Street, Middletown Historic District, Louisville, KY 40243; Office 502-245-7474; Fax 502-245-7025; Toll Free 1-866-431-3599; email bstempien@thattorneys.com; website http://www.thslaw.co. The message is accompanied by standard Privileged and Confidential notices.

Prior to June, the thread goes further back to an April 24, 2023, email from Sarena to Brian (with Aaron copied), in which she apologizes for a delay and attaches the Plaintiff’s Responses to Discovery Requests. She notes that deposition dates are fairly flexible and asks if the client is available on May 23, 25, 30, or June 1, offering to conduct the depositions via Zoom or at the client’s office. She references attachments: NOS Resp to DC Disc R (April 18, 2023), Adkins Resp to Disc Req - Final.pdf (April 18, 2023), and Downs Resp to Disc Req - Final.pdf (April 18, 2023). This email also includes the Whaley Law Firm’s standard signature with the same privilege and confidentiality notices and the indication that Sarena’s email address is the new one.

Earlier still, on April 21, 2023, Aaron Whaley forwarded a message from Brian Stempien to Aaron and to Beth Alexander. Brian explains that his insurer is pressuring him to file a motion to compel and asks for depositions and discovery dates, requesting that Aaron coordinate and provide the dates. Brian’s contact information (same as above) is included in this forwarded thread.

In summary, the deposition scheduling in this matter progressed through several correspondences from April through June 2023. Key points include:
- April 21, 2023: Brian requests deposition dates and discovery coordination; asks Aaron to assist and to coordinate with Beth.
- April 24, 2023: Sarena provides plaintiff discovery responses, proposes deposition dates (May 23, 25, 30, or June 1), and offers Zoom or in-office depositions; attachments are included.
- June 2, 2023: Brian asks to set depositions in June and to contact Beth for dates; requests a call.
- June 6, 2023: Sarena identifies available dates for depositions (June 20, 22, 27, or 29) and proposes taking Nail’s deposition the same day; anticipates a full day for all three depositions; notes Sarena’s new email address.
- June 6, 2023: Beth responds that June 29 is the only date Brian can accommodate for two depositions and that he will not agree to three in one day; she asks for alternative dates the following week to schedule Nail’s deposition at their office; provides Beth’s contact details.

All of these messages include the standard attorney-privilege and confidentiality disclosures, the practice of noting “No Attorney-Client Relationship,” and, in several emails, references to attached documents and image attachments referenced as embedded images within the messages. The communications collectively map out the coordination among Destiny Adkins’s case team and opposing counsel toward scheduling the depositions of Stephanie Nail and related parties.

episodes.natural_language:
This note documents the deposition scheduling discussions in the Destiny Adkins personal injury matter (Adkins & Downs v. Stephanie Nail & Allstate). The exchange spans an April 2023 email and several June 2023 messages among the plaintiff’s and defense counsel, centered on arranging depositions for Ms. Nail and the other parties, with an emphasis on minimizing the number of depositions in one day.

On April 24, 2023, Sarena Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm informed Brian Stempien of Travis Herbert & Stempien that they were apologetic for the delay and attached the plaintiffs’ responses to discovery. She noted that deposition dates were flexible and asked whether counsel and their client were available on May 23, 25, 30, or June 1, and that depositions could be conducted either via Zoom or in the defense office. The email referenced attachments containing the plaintiffs’ responses to the discovery requests. Sarena’s signature blocks included her contact information and new email address.

On June 2, 2023, Brian Stempien responded to Aaron Whaley and Sarena, urging that the depositions for the clients be set in June if possible. He asked Aaron and Sarena to contact Beth concerning dates and indicated that Aaron should call him when available.

On June 6, 2023, at 10:51 AM, Sarena sent a reply to Beth Alexander stating that their office was available for depositions on June 20, 22, 27, or 29, and that they would like to take Mrs. Nail’s deposition on the same day, anticipating a full day for all three depositions. Sarena’s message was cc’d to Brian Stempien and Aaron Whaley, with her contact details reaffirmed in the signature block.

Later that same day, at 12:09 PM, Beth Alexander replied that June 29 was the only date among the proposed options on which Brian was available for two depositions; she noted that Brian would not agree to three depositions in one day and asked for alternative dates in the following week for scheduling Ms. Nail’s deposition at their office.

Also on June 6, at 12:23 PM, Sarena responded, acknowledging that three depositions in a single day are a lot. She suggested that because the week of the 4th of July is the following week, they could do the 6th, or, looking at the week after that, the 11th or 12th. Her message included her standard contact details and reiterated the scheduling possibilities.

For reference, the email chain included multiple professional signatures with the parties’ law firms and contact information, including Sarena M. Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm in Louisville, KY; Beth Alexander, paralegal to Brian Stempien at Travis Herbert & Stempien, Louisville; and Brian D. Stempien of Travis Herbert & Stempien, with their respective office addresses and telephone numbers. The thread also contained the customary attorney-privilege disclaimers typical of such communications.

Destiny Adkins is the client in the motor vehicle accident matter Destiny-Adkins-MVA-04-16-2021, styled Adkins & Downs v. Stephanie Nail & Allstate. The correspondence below records pre-trial deposition scheduling and a status update on the deposition of Stephanie Nail.

In the series of June 6, 2023 emails, the Whaley Law Firm and Travis Herbert & Stempien coordinated the deposition logistics. Sarena Tuttle, a litigation paralegal at The Whaley Law Firm, sent Beth Alexander, paralegal to Brian Stempien at Travis Herbert & Stempien, a notice to take deposition of Mrs. Nail for July 12, 2023, starting at 2:00 PM in Beth Alexander’s office, as agreed. Earlier that day, Beth asked whether the plaintiff’s deposition would be taken at the defense’s office or the plaintiff’s office. Sarena replied that they prefer Zoom, but they could conduct the deposition at Beth’s office if needed. Beth then responded, indicating appreciation and that she would forward the notice as soon as possible. An additional message from Sarena conveyed that she would get the notice over to Beth as soon as possible. The formal deposition notice itself was delivered by Sarena on June 6, 2023 at 1:39 PM, specifying that the deposition of Mrs. Nail would occur on July 12, 2023, at 2:00 PM in Beth Alexander’s office, as agreed, in the matter Adkins & Downs v. Stephanie Nail & Allstate. The exchanges included standard privileged and confidential disclaimers typical of the firms involved, including statements that no attorney-client relationship is created by sending or receiving email, and notices about IRS Circular 230 tax-disclosure requirements.

The parties and contact details involved in these communications were: Beth A. Alexander, Paralegal to Brian Stempien of Travis Herbert & Stempien, located in the Jefferson Marders Building, 11507 Main Street, Louisville, KY 40243, with phone (502) 245-7474 and fax (502) 245-7025; and Sarena M. Tuttle, Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, located at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, with direct dial (502) 357-9971, main office (502) 583-4022 ext 104, and email Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com (noting the address for the new email address). The messages also carried the firms’ standard “Privileged and Confidential” notices, indicating that the information is attorney-privileged and confidential and that dissemination to unintended recipients is prohibited, along with the standard disclaimer that no attorney-client relationship is created by email, and the required Circular 230 tax disclosures.

On July 11, 2023, Beth Alexander wrote to Sarena Tuttle reporting difficulty confirming the deposition. Specifically, Beth stated that they had been unable to reach Ms. Nail to confirm the deposition scheduled for tomorrow, and that Brian Stempien was confident she would not appear. Beth noted that they had not been able to locate Ms. Nail since their initial conversation, and that she would inform Sarena if Ms. Nail’s status changed.

This narrative reflects the chain of scheduling discussions, the formal deposition notice, the parties and firms involved, the proposed deposition timing and location, the preference for Zoom versus in-person attendance, and the status update indicating an anticipated nonappearance risk for Ms. Nail as of July 11, 2023.

Case: Destiny-Adkins-MVA-04-16-2021. Client: Destiny Adkins. This matter involves Adkins & Downs v. Stephanie Nail & Allstate.

In June 2023, the parties began coordinating the deposition of Mrs. Nail in the Adkins case. On June 6, 2023, Sarena M. Tuttle, a litigation paralegal and workers’ compensation case manager for The Whaley Law Firm, sent a notice to Beth A. Alexander, a paralegal at Travis Herbert & Stempien, regarding the deposition. The message included a notice to take the deposition of Mrs. Nail on July 12, 2023, beginning at 2:00 p.m., to be held at Beth’s office “as agreed.” Earlier that day, Beth asked whether the Plaintiff’s deposition would be at their office or theirs. Sarena responded that they preferred Zoom but could do Beth’s office, and Beth replied, “Great… thanks.” The notice was provided in a follow-up message from Sarena, dated June 6, 2023 at 1:39 p.m., stating the deposition would start at 2:00 p.m. on July 12, 2023, at Beth’s office as agreed.

The June 6 exchange also included standard attorney-client and tax-disclosure disclaimers typical of the firms’ email communications. Beth’s and Sarena’s signatures identify their roles and contact details: Sarena Tuttle is with The Whaley Law Firm, located at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; direct line 502-357-9971 and office line 502-583-4022 ext 104; email Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com (noting a new address). Beth Alexander is a Paralegal to Brian Stempien at Travis Herbert & Stempien, located in the Jefferson Marders Building, 11507 Main Street, Louisville, KY 40243; direct line 502-245-7474; fax 502-245-7025.

On July 11, 2023, Beth Alexander emailed to report difficulty confirming the deposition with Ms. Nail for the next day, stating that they had been unable to reach Ms. Nail and that Brian believed she would not appear. She noted they had not located Ms. Nail since their initial conversation and that she would update if her status changed. In response, Sarena Tuttle replied, “Ok, thanks for the update. I will let Aaron & Bryce know as well,” indicating that others at the firm would be alerted to the situation.

The email thread shows the depositions for the Adkins matter were being scheduled with flexibility regarding in-person versus remote participation, conditional on Ms. Nail’s availability, and that updates would be communicated promptly among the involved counsel and paralegals.

Destiny Adkins, the client in the Destiny-Adkins-MVA-04-16-2021 case, had a deposition confirmed for July 12, 2023 (docket number 84274). The deposition was scheduled in the matter of Destiny Adkins & Juanita Downs v. Stephanie Nail, et al., with Stephanie Nail listed as the judge/witness. The location for the proceedings was Travis Herbert & Stempien, PLLC, Jefferson Marders Building, 11507 Main Street, Louisville, Kentucky, 40202, and the contact phone number given was 502-245-7474. The client listed on the confirmation was Aaron Whaley, Esquire, of The Whaley Law Firm. The date and time shown for the deposition were July 12, 2023 at 2:00 PM.

On July 11, 2023, Kristina Wenninger, Scheduling Manager for Kentuckiana Court Reporters, sent an email with the subject Re: Confirmation for 7/12/2023 (84274). The email attached the confirmation for tomorrow’s proceeding and requested that it be reviewed to confirm whether it would go forward as scheduled or if revisions were necessary. The confirmation indicated that the only requested service was a Court Reporter (the box for Court Reporter was checked), while other services—Videographer, Interpreter, Conference Room, ZOOM Connection, and Telephone Conference—were not selected. The header of that message included Kentuckiana Court Reporters’ office details: A: 730 West Main Street, Suite 101, Louisville, KY 40202; P: (502) 589-2273; F: (502) 584-0119; E: Schedule@kentuckianareporters.com. The message also included a note thanking the recipient for scheduling with them and contained a standard confidentiality disclaimer about the information being privileged or confidential and not to be filed publicly.

Earlier that same morning, at 11:34 AM, Kristina Wenninger wrote to the recipients that the attached confirmation should be reviewed to confirm whether the proceeding would proceed as scheduled or if revisions were necessary. At 11:41 AM, Sarena M. Tuttle, Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager for The Whaley Law Firm, replied: Good afternoon, we are still on for tomorrow, and as far as she was aware there had not been any cancellations. Her signature included her title and contact information, and she noted the new email address: Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com. The timing and sequence continued with a brief 11:43 AM reply from Kristina Wenninger simply saying “Thank you!” followed by the same scheduling details from Kentuckiana Court Reporters. Finally, at 12:09 PM on July 11, 2023, Sarena responded that, just moments after her prior reply, the Defense canceled the deposition. She apologized for the change in status. Her message again carried her contact details and the note to use her new email address.

Her direct line was 502-357-9971, her office line 502-583-4022 ext. 104, and her email address was Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com, with a note indicating the address was a new email address.

In a prior message at around 11:34 AM on July 11, 2023, Kristina Wenninger had attached the confirmation for the following day’s proceeding and requested review to confirm whether the schedule would proceed as written or whether revisions were needed. The confirmation listed a single selected option: Court Reporter (checked), with other services (Videographer, Interpreter, Conference Room, ZOOM Connection, Telephone Conference) left unchecked.

Sarena Tuttle then replied later in the morning, around 11:41 AM, indicating that the deposition was still on for tomorrow and that, to her knowledge, there had not been any cancellations. She reiterated her role and contact details, including her new email address.

Subsequently, at approximately 12:09 PM, she informed that, just moments after the earlier message, the defense canceled the deposition. She offered apologies for the change.

Following that sequence, McKenna responded at 4:10 PM UTC on July 11, 2023, confirming that they would remove the matter from their calendar and would send a cancellation confirmation shortly.

The email thread ends with a final scheduling notice reiterating the scheduled details for July 12, 2023, at 2:00 PM, with Aaron Whaley, Esquire, of The Whaley Law Firm listed as the client contact for the matter Destiny Adkins & Juanita Downs v. Stephanie Nail, et al., with Stephanie Nail identified as the witness, and the location specified as Travis Herbert & Stempien, PLLC, Jefferson Marders Building, 11507 Main Street, Louisville, Kentucky, 502-245-7474.

The closing of the thread includes a standard scheduling acknowledgment: “Thank you for scheduling with us,” followed by a confidentiality notice stating that the information in the email is intended solely for the named recipient, may be privileged or confidential, and may be exempt from disclosure under Federal Rules of Evidence 408 or other laws; recipients should not file copies of the email with publicly accessible records. The notice also cautions that if the reader is not the intended recipient or responsible for delivering the message to the intended recipient, dissemination or copying is prohibited.

The following two emails from W. Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm, were sent to Mr. Stempien at bstempien@thattorneys.com regarding the deposition of Destiny Adkins.

The first email, sent Monday, September 11, 2023 at 2:54 PM, addressed Mr. Stempien with the subject Adkins & Downs v. Nail, et al. (Jefferson Circuit 22-CI-002878). Koon reminded that on August 21, 2023 the Court entered an Order requiring the client to appear for a deposition within 30 days from entry. He noted that the deadline was quickly approaching and there had been no update to date. He asked whether the client would be able to attend the deposition so a date could be scheduled in the coming weeks. The message closed with Koon’s signature and contact details: W. Bryce Koon, Esq., The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; Phone: (502) 365-5043; Fax: (502) 237-3207. The email also carried the standard confidentiality disclaimer stating that the electronic message is intended only for the named recipient, may contain attorney‑client privileged or otherwise protected information, and that if received in error, the recipient should contact The Whaley Law Firm, with no waiver of privilege, and should not use or forward the information to any third party not intended to receive it.

The second email, the follow-up, was sent Tuesday, September 26, 2023 at 3:09:55 PM, again from W. Bryce Koon to Mr. Stempien with the same subject. In this message, Koon stated that he had not yet heard anything back regarding the deposition for Destiny Adkins. He asked whether counsel had been able to reach the client and, if so, to provide any available dates for a deposition. Case: Destiny-Adkins-MVA-04-16-2021. The client is Destiny Adkins.

This note concerns the matter of Adkins and Downs v. Nail, et al., in Jefferson Circuit Court, case number 22-CI-002878. The record is drawn from a chain of emails between counsel regarding the case.

On September 28, 2023, W. Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm, wrote to counsel about the Adkins matter. He stated, “Please see attached filed today in Jefferson Circuit Court.” His message included his standard firm signature with the firm’s contact information: The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; phone 502-365-5043; fax 502-237-3207. He also included the usual attorney-client privilege disclaimer, noting that the electronic message is intended only for the named recipient and may contain privileged or protected information; if received in error, the recipient should contact The Whaley Law Firm, not use or forward the information, and no waiver of privilege would apply.

Earlier, on October 7, 2023, Brian D. Stempien of Travis Herbert & Stempien, PLLC, replied to Bryce Koon with a scheduling inquiry. He wrote: “Counsel: We were actually able to locate Ms. Nail. How does Wednesday, October 18 at 2 o’clock in our office work for you?” The message was sent from his iPhone and was copied to acewen@ewenandkinney.com, Sarena Tuttle, and Beth Alexander. The subject line of this thread remained related to Adkins and Downs v. Nail, et al. (Jeff. Cir. 22-CI-002878).

On October 9, 2023, Bryce Koon responded to counsel with, “Counsel, This will work for us. Thank you.” His reply included the same standard confidentiality disclaimer as in his September 28 message. The communication confirms that the parties agreed to a meeting time and that the proposed date and the location—Ms. Nail’s appearance—were being scheduled in connection with the Jefferson Circuit Court case referenced above.

In sum, the email exchanges between The Whaley Law Firm and Travis Herbert & Stempien, PLLC, between September 28 and October 9, 2023, relate to a filing in Jefferson Circuit Court (case 22-CI-002878) and to scheduling a meeting concerning Ms. Nail for Wednesday, October 18, at 2:00 p.m. in the office of the opposing counsel. The thread also displays the standard privilege notices and contact information for the involved firms.

Case: Destiny-Adkins-MVA-04-16-2021. Client: Destiny Adkins. This notes the matter Adkins and Downs v. Nail, et al. in Jefferson Circuit Court (case number 22-CI-002878). The following is a sequence of email communications among counsel for the parties.

On September 28, 2023, W. Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm, wrote to counsel with a brief update: please see the attached filing that was submitted today in Jefferson Circuit Court. The message included his firm’s contact information—The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; phone 502-365-5043; fax 502-237-3207—and carried a standard attorney-client privilege disclaimer stating the electronic message is intended only for the named recipient and that recipients should not use or forward the information if received in error. A spam- and virus-scan notice from Proofpoint Essentials appeared at the bottom of the email.

Two weeks later, on October 7, 2023, Brian D. Stempien, of Travis Herbert & Stempien, PLLC, replied to Bryce Koon with a scheduling proposal. He wrote that they had actually located Ms. Nail and asked whether Wednesday, October 18, at 2:00 p.m. in their office would work for Bryce Koon’s side. Stempien provided his firm’s details: Travis Herbert & Stempien, PLLC, in the Jefferson Marders Building, 11507 Main Street, Middletown Historic District, Louisville, KY 40243; office phone 502-245-7474; fax 502-245-7025; toll-free 1-866-431-3599; email bstempien@thattorneys.com.

On October 9, 2023, at 11:16 a.m., Bryce Koon replied, signaling agreement with the proposed arrangement. He wrote, “Counsel, This will work for us,” and included his standard firm signature and confidentiality disclaimer indicating the message is intended only for the named recipient and should not be used or shared if received in error. His contact details were The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; phone 502-365-5043; fax 502-237-3207.

Later that same day, October 9, 2023, at 3:26 p.m. UTC, Brian Stempien sent a follow-up: “Assuming this works for Campbell, we will get this set up. Let me know if you are not alright with doing this here. I would like to minimize the logistical challenges for obvious reasons.” He closed with his Travis Herbert & Stempien signature block and the same standard privileged/ confidential notices. The email reiterated that the message and any attachments are intended for the recipient and that sending or receipt does not establish an attorney-client relationship; it also included the IRS Circular 230 tax information disclaimer about the disclosure obligations for tax advice in written communications.

The thread includes additional formalities typical of attorney communications. Bryce Koon’s messages consistently carried the confidentiality notices stating the electronic communication is for the named recipient and should not be disseminated if received in error, and Brian Stempien’s messages carried the same notices, including the standard disclaimer about no attorney-client relationship being established by sending or receiving emails and the IRS tax-advice warning where applicable.

Throughout, the exchanges were CC’d to additional recipients to share context: acewen@ewenandkinney.com, Sarena Tuttle, and Beth Alexander, with the communications preserving their respective roles in the matter. The messages also contained the usual electronic-disclaimer language and a note that the emails may include attorney-privileged or otherwise protected information.

In summary, the communication chain from September 28 to October 9, 2023, reflects counsel coordinating a meeting to discuss the Adkins and Downs v. Nail matter, with a proposed in-office meeting to discuss Ms. Nail’s location (having located her) and a proposed date of Wednesday, October 18, at 2:00 p.m., contingent on Campbell’s agreement. The thread includes complete contact details for both law firms, standard confidentiality and privilege notices, and the customary notices about no attorney-client relationship being created by email.

episodes.natural_language:
Initial client contact on January 29, 2024, with Destiny Adkins regarding the motor vehicle accident case Destiny-Adkins-MVA-04-16-2021.

 Please find attached the Motion for Special Bailiff filed moments ago
via CourtNet Envelope 7387377. It appears Defendant Demetrius Turner
received notice from the Sheriff and set up an appointment to be served,

Sarena M. Tuttle

This note concerns Destiny Adkins, the client in the Destiny-Adkins-MVA-04-16-2021 matter. In Jefferson County case 22-CI-002878, Adkins/Downs v Nail/Turner & Allstate, a Motion for Special Bailiff has been filed. The motion was attached and filed moments ago via CourtNet, identified as Envelope 7387377.

According to the email, Defendant Demetrius Turner had received notice from the Sheriff and set up an appointment to be served. However, Turner did not appear for the appointment, and, per the Sheriff, he has stopped responding to the Sheriff’s attempts to contact or serve him. At this time, counsel is requesting that a Special Bailiff be appointed to perfect service.

The message was sent by Sarena M. Tuttle, Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, to counsel A. Ewen and Brian Stempien, with Greg Whaley and Bryce Koon CC’d. The email was dated Wednesday, February 21, 2024, at 3:04:45 PM Eastern Time. It notes that the Motion for Special Bailiff was attached and filed via CourtNet Envelope 7387377. The Whaley Law Firm’s contact details are 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; direct line 502-357-9971; office line 502-583-4022 ext 104; email Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com, with a note indicating a new email address.

Destiny Adkins is the client in the Destiny-Adkins-MVA-04-16-2021 case. On May 16, 2024, at 3:49 PM, a new voice message from the Kentucky State Office of the Administrative Office of the Courts (phone: 502-595-4588) was received for Sarena Tuttle (phone: 502-357-9971). The notification came via RingCentral, with an email header from RingCentral notifying the message at 19:49:57 UTC. The message was 23 seconds long.

The voicemail, left by Daniel Bob from the court administrator's office, stated: “Hi, Sarena, this is Daniel Bob calling from the court administrator's office. Just let you know I got the order signed by Judge Hayner and it is been entered and it is ready for pick up by your bailiff, Allison Pitzer, and you are also going to be receiving a copy of the order signed to your office as well. Thank you and have a great day.” The note indicates that the order has been signed by Judge Hayner, entered, and is ready for pickup by Bailiff Allison Pitzer, with a signed copy to be sent to Sarena Tuttle’s office as well. Destiny Adkins is the client in the motor vehicle accident matter Destiny Adkins, et al. v. Stephanie Nail, et al., Jefferson Circuit Court case number 22-CI-002878, commonly referenced in the file as Destiny-Adkins-MVA-04-16-2021. The note documents a sequence of email exchanges between counsel regarding whether to dismiss certain parties from the case and how that might be conditioned on admissions or statements in pleadings and discovery responses. The parties to the communications include The Whaley Law Firm, representing Destiny Adkins, and Travis Herbert & Stempien, PLLC, representing the opposing side, with other recipients copied on the messages. The case caption reflects the underlying motor vehicle accident on April 16, 2021.

In an email dated January 16, 2024, W. Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm, sent counsel correspondence to Brian D. Stempien of Travis Herbert & Stempien, PLLC, and kpkinney@ewenandkinney.com, with the subject Destiny Adkins, et al. v. Stephanie Nail, et al. (Jefferson Circuit 22-CI-002878). The body stated, “Good afternoon counsel, Please see attached filed today in Jefferson Circuit Court.” The message was cc’d to Destiny Adkins MVA 04/16/2021 – Filevine Project Email Address (DestinyAdkinsMVAZ1161425@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com) and Juanita Nicole Downs MVA 4/16/2021 – Filevine Project Email Address (JuanitaNicoleDownsMVAZ954678@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com). The Whaley Law Firm’s signature provided the firm’s address at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, with a phone number of (502) 365-5043 and a fax number of (502) 364-9363. The email carried the standard attorney-client privilege disclaimer asserting confidentiality and the prohibition on dissemination or use if the message was received in error, along with the notice that no attorney-client relationship is created by sending or receiving e-mails, and included an IRS Circular 230 tax disclaimer.

On July 22, 2024, Brian D. Stempien, of Travis Herbert & Stempien, PLLC, replied to Bryce Koon and Aaron Whaley, with Sarena Tuttle cc’d, under the subject RE: Destiny Adkins, et al. v. Stephanie Nail, et al. (Jefferson Circuit 22-CI-002878). Stempien asked, “Aaron and Bryce: Are you guys going to let Ms. Nail out of this case? Give me a call if you would like to discuss.” Stempien’s contact information appeared in the message: Travis Herbert & Stempien, PLLC, Jefferson Marders Building, 11507 Main Street, Middletown Historic District, Louisville, KY 40243; Office: (502) 245-7474; Fax: (502) 245-7025; Toll Free: 1 (866) 431-3599; Email: bstempien@thattorneys.com. The message included the firm’s standard confidentiality and privilege notices, the “No Attorney-Client Relationship” disclaimer, and the accompanying IRS Circular 230 tax disclosures.

Earlier, on September 3, 2024, Stempien again addressed the matter in an email beginning, “Guys: Are you going to let my lady out of this case?”—a reference to Ms. Nail. The message was sent from Stempien to the same recipients and included the same customary firm signature blocks and disclaimers, emphasizing privilege and confidentiality, the absence of an attorney-client relationship, and the tax-disclosure language required by Circular 230.

Throughout the correspondence, the CC list consistently included Destiny Adkins MVA 04/16/2021 – Filevine Project Email Address and Juanita Nicole Downs MVA 4/16/2021 – Filevine Project Email Address, reflecting their involvement or potential relevance to filings or updates in Jefferson Circuit Court. The emails consistently carried the standard confidentiality and privilege notices typical of attorney communications, including warnings about inadvertent receipt, the lack of an attorney-client relationship by e-mail, and, where applicable, the tax-disclosure language mandated by the IRS Circular 230. The Whaley Law Firm’s contact details—712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; phone (502) 365-5043; fax (502) 364-9363—are reflected in the January 16, 2024 message, while Travis Herbert & Stempien, PLLC’s details—11507 Main Street, Middletown Historic District, Louisville, KY 40243; Office (502) 245-7474; Fax (502) 245-7025; Toll Free (866) 431-3599—appear in the July 22, 2024 message.

episodes.natural_language:
Destiny Adkins, the client in the motor vehicle accident matter Destiny Adkins v. Stephanie Nail, et al., Jefferson Circuit Court case 22-CI-002878 (designated in the file as Destiny-Adkins-MVA-04-16-2021), is the subject of an email exchange dated September 3, 2024. The correspondence involves counsel Bryce Koon of The Whaley Law Firm and Brian D. Stempien of Travis Herbert & Stempien, PLLC, along with several other recipients listed in the CC field, including Destiny Adkins MVA-related Filevine project emails and Juanita Nicole Downs MVA-related Filevine project emails. The overall topic concerns possible dismissal of certain parties from the case and the conditions for such dismissal, within the context of the Jefferson Circuit Court docket.

On January 16, 2024, Bryce Koon sent an email to Brian Stempien and kpkinney@ewenandkinney.com, with Sarena Tuttle CC’d, under the subject Destiny Adkins, et al. v. Stephanie Nail, et al. (Jefferson Circuit 22-CI-002878). In that message, Koon wrote: “Good afternoon counsel, Please see attached filed today in Jefferson Circuit Court.” The email was sent from The Whaley Law Firm, with Bryce Koon’s contact information provided: W. Bryce Koon, Esq., The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; Phone: (502) 365-5043; Fax: (502) 364-9363. The message carried the standard attorney-client privilege disclaimer and related notices typical of such communications, including statements about no attorney-client relationship arising from the transmission and references to IRS Circular 230 disclosures where applicable.

On July 22, 2024, Brian D. Stempien replied to Bryce Koon and Aaron Whaley, with Sarena Tuttle CC’d, under the subject Destiny Adkins, et al. v. Stephanie Nail, et al. (Jefferson Circuit 22-CI-002878). In his message, Stempien asked: “Aaron and Bryce: Are you guys going to let Ms. Nail out of this case? Give me a call if you would like to discuss.” He signed with his firm’s contact details: Travis Herbert & Stempien, PLLC, Jefferson Marders Building, 11507 Main Street, Middletown Historic District, Louisville, KY 40243; Office: (502) 245-7474; Fax: (502) 245-7025; Toll Free: 1-866-431-3599; Email: bstempien@thattorneys.com; Website: http://www.thslaw.co. The message included the firm’s customary privileged and confidential notices, confirming that no attorney-client relationship is created by receipt and reiterating the standard disclaimers and policy statements common in such communications. The email chain also includes references to the attachments and a general warning about privilege and tax-disclosure requirements as part of the signature blocks, mirroring the practice seen in other emails from the same exchanges.

Earlier in the chain, on September 3, 2024, at approximately 12:10 PM, Stempien sent a follow-up message asking: “Guys: Are you going to let my lady out of this case?” This message, like the others, included Stempien’s contact information and the firm’s customary confidentiality and privilege notices, including explicit disclaimers about attorney-client relationships and the guidelines required by IRS Circular 230. The signature block contains his office address in Louisville, with the same general warnings about confidentiality and the prohibition on disseminating the content if the recipient is not the intended recipient.

Shortly thereafter, at 12:19 PM on the same day, Bryce Koon replied to Brian Stempien with a direct conditional offer: “Good afternoon Brian, We will agree to dismiss your client from the case if she amends her Answer and/or discovery responses to state that Defendant Turner was operating her vehicle with permission. Outside of that, I do not believe we can agree to voluntary dismissal of your client.” He provided his standard Whaley Law Firm signature, including the firm’s Louisville address (712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222), phone number (502) 365-5043, and fax (502) 237-3207. The message again carried the firm’s privilege and confidentiality notices and related disclaimers.

In sum, the September 2024 email thread shows ongoing settlement discussions about voluntary dismissal of a party from Destiny Adkins v. Stephanie Nail, et al., with a specific condition: the opposing party would be dismissed if Destiny Adkins’ Answer and/or discovery responses were amended to assert that Defendant Turner operated the vehicle with permission. Absent that amendment, the parties indicated they were not willing to pursue voluntary dismissal. The correspondence also reflects a broader pattern of coordination among counsel across the Whaley Law Firm and the Stempien firm, the inclusion of multiple Filevine project email addresses in CC lines, and the presence of standard attorney-client privilege and confidentiality notices in each message.
